text: ah hi everyone ghoul that he's spooked a
now here the Internet's creepiest music
nerd and it's time for a review of the
new clipping album there existed an
addiction to blue this is the newest
record from experimental hip hop trio
clipping clipping to this day features
the production and sound design of
William Hudson as well as Jonathan
Snipes and of course the rapping and the
storytelling of mr. Davi Diggs
now since turning heads and turning
noise rap on its head in 2013 with their
mixtape mid-city the trio has
consistently proven themselves to be one
of the most creative acts in hip-hop
today whether it's through their
spectacular Sub Pop debut a year later
or with the narrative concept album
splendour and misery in 2016 a record
about an escapee on an intergalactic
slave ship and the ship falls in love
with him it's complicated anyway it's
been a few years now since we have heard
from clipping in a studio album capacity
though it seems like each members kept
pretty busy with their own respective
solo projects in film work soundtrack
work some solo stuff too but despite
each member being split into their own
lane for a little bit they have convened
on to this new record in such a way
where it sounds like they just haven't
missed a beat because they come through
with one of their most cohesive focused
conceptual and Big Idea records yet now
there existed in addiction to blood
isn't that far off sonically and
thematically from a lot of clippings
previous work there is a lot of
storytelling on this thing a lot of very
fast verbose rapping the production is
noisy vaguely industrial at points but
above all this new album here is scary
it's frightening it's kind of the
linchpin of the record one could
potentially classify this project even
as horrorcore with it's morbid
infatuations all of its blood all of its
gruesome details so yeah there's a lot
of bodies buried on this album it's kind
of creepy though again for clipping that
is not entirely new what our tracks like
body and blood or break the glass if not
attempt at inducing fear but basically
that whole fear thing on there existed
in addiction to blood they push it so
much further it is the focus of the
album they are dropping this project
just before Halloween for Christ's sake
there are lyrics on this thing
referencing bad horror movie plots and
jump scares also pretty much every
instrumental on this thing feels like an
overt nod to horror movie soundtracks
both new and old whether you're talking
about the heavy and droning Club down or
the track nothing is safe whose
persistent pianos and synth sound very
John Carpenter inspired also you have
some of the interlude cuts on here such
as haunting which is I think a very old
vintage tape of a woman describing
herself as being haunted by Satan her
descriptions are pretty unnerving and
then there's also possession which
sounds like a audio clip from an old
horror movie it's very campy a little
corny but still adds to the character of
the record so the trio's appreciation of
horror as an art form as a medium of
expression is very much on display on
this project but even though again I
think you could effectively categorize
this record as a horrorcore album
there's very little about what inspires
it that seems rooted in horror core as a
genre there's not a whole lot here that
sounds like or reminds me of old three 6
mafia or the Memphis scene back in the
day in general
Brotha Lynch hung or ICP or grave
diggers and not that I think clipping
has anything against those artists they
probably enjoy a great deal of them but
clearly the sound and style of this
album is a lot less about horrorcore as
a music genre up until this point and
more about trying to embody expressions
of horror
especially in film in their own way on
this record in such a way that it leads
to a unique and almost cinematic
experience which shouldn't be too
surprising because when you look at the
background of the trio you have
soundtrack work you have acting you have
writing you have sound design there are
numerous tracks on this project just
like with splendor and misery where
Dobby does
rapping speedily over these mostly drum
'less instrumentals that have huge
atmospheres huge droning bass again with
the track club down the massive hits of
industrial noise on the song are huge
the song he dead also features very
little in terms of rhythm but still
there's lots of eerie droning tones on
this track distant metallic bangs the
IDI balloon chorus is great and the
instrumental on the show features all of
these metallic glitches and distortions
occasionally bringing in some handclaps
to shore up the pace of the song though
I will say this isn't one of my favorite
tracks on the record compositionally and
it's one of the few moments here that
makes me wish there were maybe some more
traditionally musical elements placed
here and there on the record just to
break things up and just add it a bit
more sweetness even if it is bitter
sweetness
especially on cuts where WT is bringing
the most head-bobbing flows but still I
do love the storyline on this track
which seems like it's about a torturous
murderer who's breaking bones and
cutting skin and sawing off shoulders
and I guess he's subjecting other people
to all of this it's it's almost like a
saw in a way but what else would you
expect from an album that puts you
face-to-face on the cover with 49 nails
just pointed right at you like you're
stuck in a death machine even more
challenging those the track all in your
head which features all of these deadpan
refrains from dahveed wild hurried
ranting from counterfeit Madison
thumping sparse rhythms metallic clangs
lots of synthetic noise but then there
is this chilling dusty sad chord
progression that introduces itself and
we get this wonderful vocal passage from
Robin Hood it feels like the Sun coming
up after a long dark night of everyone
just slaughtering each other in the
streets it's bright out it's a new day
but then all the blood and all the death
and all the mayhem is is revealed not
crazy about the first portion again but
I do love the singing on this portion of
the track feels vaguely gospel inspired
too it's easily one of the most powerful
moments on the entire record the song
attunement sees dahveed putting more of
his flows over these industrial sounds
more heavy bass more noise more fast rap
flows which i think are great i also
love how the numerous references to
burning on this track lead us
effectively into the album's final cut
the 18 minute long piano burning which
sounds like a field recording of a piano
burning and that's it
for 18 minutes still another track with
the same instrumental type as attunement
does make me wish there was a bit more
sonic variety or just variants across
the record I guess the song does still
add to more of this feel of the the
sound design of this record feeling akin
to that of a modern horror movie trailer
but a bit harsher a bit noisier almost
as if the people crafting the trailer
listened to a lot of Whitehouse or
perience or MERS bow or maybe even some
throbbing gristle thankfully the more
accessible cuts on this record of which
there are plenty are consistently great
and versatile again the track nothing is
safe which is essentially about a trap
house a trap spot which ends up being
under siege everyone thinks they're
locked and loaded they're safe nothing's
gonna happen they're protected that does
not end up being the case though and the
carpenter' inspired instrumental and the
tense rapping and storytelling from
dahveed just keeps you on the edge of
your seat we eventually reach a point on
the track where we have these panoramic
layers of scents tight trap rhythms also
the track key dead which again at
balloon kicks off perfectly his singing
and the melody almost reminds me of an
old young father song but overall the
vibe of this track is a lot droney er a
lot creepier dahveed's intense rapping
on this track basically flips an
all-too-common trope in today's news
police brutality depicting a police
killing almost as if you are being
chased down by monsters by almost
werewolf like creatures who are going to
kill you the track la mala ordina is a
somewhat weird change of pace given that
the that buzzy lead synthesizers and
dusty lo-fi drums sound like something
off of a black moth super rainbow record
it's a little kooky the track also
features guest verses from metal candy
as well as Benny the butcher and if
you're familiar with those two rappers
you can see why obviously W would use
this as an opportunity to take a lot of
themes of violence and drug dealing and
do a bit of an eerie flip on that also I
should mention that the last minute or
so of this track is really just a harsh
wall of noise and it is [ __ ] awesome
and as long as we're talking about
features on this thing my favorite is
probably let chats off the track run for
your life chat basically plays a a
killer cur grimy southern flow and twang
adds a refreshing dynamic to the
tracklist also I have to talk about how
genius the production on this track is
all the found sounds and field
recordings give you the feeling of the
protagonist being outside existing in
the space that they're rapping about
also there's a moment where a beat
swells under dahveed's
voice that he's rapping in time with but
the beat arrives by way of a car driving
by which is like one of the weirdest and
most insane ideas I think I've ever
heard worked into a hip-hop track but is
oh my god amazing though this really
thick bassy beat pops in when chats
feature pops in later on the track in
full and it sounds fantastic I love that
we get this slow transition to slow
progression to this point that is so
fulfilling it's so gratifying the song
blood of the thing I think is really
where the album's title and main theme
gets explained pretty thoroughly with
dahveed as a protagonist explaining the
society the context that he lives in
basically having this infatuation this
desire to consume violence murder and
this also comes along I think with a
commentary on normalization as well
because it seems almost as if at points
on the song davido is trying to escape
the blood escape the murder but then
he's almost being indoctrinated into it
like a cult love the sputtering beat on
this track the really prominent and
strange esoteric vocal samples the dusty
chants in the background as well
Debbie eats flows just dart in every
direction and are impeccably executed I
guess
I should also mention the track story 7
which for longtime clipping fans is
another addition to the story series
every major clipping project so far has
had a story song on it and they usually
end up being a highlight of some sort
and occasionally they even reference
each other the story on this record
though still plays into the murderous
and creepy fantastical and ghoulish
themes of the record though as this
story is essentially about a woman who
turns into a beast I'm assuming a
werewolf because there's reference to a
there being a full moon on the track and
she's basically killing men that she's
seducing she runs into a character from
a previous story that clipping has done
though I'm not going to spoil too much
of the story beyond that the
instrumental on this one is really odd
though the transitions are breakneck and
don't even seem logical but the more I
listen to it the more I found it to be
incredibly catchy
how did Orion glitchy and occasionally
harsh it is almost remind me of moments
off of clippings wriggle EP which is not
necessarily a bad thing as I think
that's one of their more interesting
projects overall though I think this is
yet another great album from clipping a
few tracks that I thought paled in
comparison to others along the tracklist
sure maybe the final cut is a little
excessive with it being as long as it is
but I still think this project showcases
a lot of great rapping storytelling
production and sound craft great theme
and concept even if it makes this album
maybe one of the more niche records and
clippings discography but still I see no
reason not to make this record a
tradition in your yearly Halloween music
rotation though I would not call this a
Halloween album though it just happens
to be a horrifying scary record that
clipping smartly dropped near Halloween
so people would kind of be in the creepy
spirit that's just good marketing okay
it's just good marketing everything else
about the record though is good music
even if occasionally I think clipping
does go out of their way to sacrifice
some of the musical elements of this
record and even with their last record a
little bit too just so the narrative
shines a bit brighter but given how
unique intriguing and entertaining
clippings narratives typically are it is
a compromise I'm totally fine with I'm
